Perspectives on WBI's FY06 Performance in Focus Countries
Violaine Le Rouzic Sara Okada
WBI Evaluation Studies EG07-121
World Bank Institute The World Bank Washington, D.C.
November 2006   PERSPECTIVES ON WBI'S FY06 PERFORMANCE IN FOCUS COUNTRIES
To assess the World Bank Institute's performance in its 34 focus countries in FY06 from the perspective of operational staff, the Institute's Evaluation Group (WBIEG) surveyed 61 senior members of country management teams (CMT) in early FY07.1 The surveys asked respondents to provide their opinions of WBI's activities in the countries for which they were responsible. Five people received two or more surveys because of their responsibilities for several WBI focus countries, such as in central Asia.
For each country, the WBI's Regional Coordination Unit (WBIRC) identified the two CMT members it believed to be most knowledgeable about WBI's activities, typically the country director and country manager. WBI's vice president asked these people to complete the online survey on August 14, and sent a reminder on September 5, 2006. In mid September, WBIEG's manager called and emailed nonrespondents, again soliciting their response.
Response rate and respondent profile
Of the 61 people surveyed, 51 responded (84 percent), providing information on 32 of the 34 focus countries. No one responded from Ghana or Burkina Faso. Table 1 provides the response rates by region.

1  Quantitative results
The survey was intentionally brief to encourage responses, and the reader should be aware that responses reflect opinions and perceptions about WBI's performance and effectiveness. In several instances, because some respondents are based in Washington, the respondents may be familiar with WBI's activities and personnel in Washington but not have first-hand experience with WBI's activities, the participants' reactions to them, or how well WBI's efforts have addressed particular gaps or deficiencies in capacity.
With these caveats in mind, it is nonetheless important to note that the respondents were pleased with the services WBI provided in FY06. Senior operational counterparts particularly appreciated the way WBI consulted with them to select its activities, with 98 percent rating the consultation in FY06 as satisfactory to a large extent or better. The consultations were perceived to be effective in helping WBI understand the capacity development needs of the country and align its activities with these needs (87 percent rating these aspects to a large extent or higher). See table 3.
While WBI performs well in a priori consultation, it could improve its information to the CMT about the activities' results. The latter question (Q2) was rated significantly lower than the former (Q1a).2
Though the activities were aligned to a large extent or better with the perceived capacity needs in each focus country (Q3a), the effectiveness in building capacity in the countries (Q3b) was rated less well. Seventy-three percent of the respondents indicated that WBI's activities were effective to a large extent or better in building capacity.
Operational counterparts considered that WBI activities were slightly better, better, or much better than equivalent capacity development activities from local organizations (87 percent) or donor organizations (81 percent). When compared with the rest of the Bank, however, 43 percent said that WBI activities were at least slightly better, and 44 percent found them to be about the same (table 4).
No significant differences were identified on any question between low-income and middle-income countries. The limited number of responses (due to the small population surveyed) prevents any meaningful comparison of the ratings per region.

3  Open-ended responses:
The survey included two open-ended questions. Respondents were asked how WBI could improve its effectiveness in each focus country and whether they had any additional comments. Forty-three people provided comments.
Overall assessment of WBI in FY06
Respondent's overall assessment of WBI was positive (30 respondents with positive assessment, 4 respondents with some critical comments, and 9 respondents without explicit judgment). Among the positive responses, 13 people explicitly noted improvements in WBI's performance over the past few years. All regions had respondents with positive assessments of WBI activities, and at least one respondent in each region reported some progress.
Assessment of relation between WBI and Bank Operations
WBI's collaboration with the country teams was well perceived and assessed positively. Similarly, respondents from all regions assessed this aspect positively. Eleven respondents indicated that they would like to see continuous collaboration, dialogue, and consultation between WBI and their country teams. Five respondents acknowledged the effective liaison between WBI and country teams but still mentioned the need for further proactive collaboration. One respondent expressed the need to develop WBI's own capacity and to "integrate more with the country team to help it with implementation."
Here is an example of one person's opinion:
Our collaboration has improved much over the past few years. The WBI team consults with the country team extensively in developing the country program and it has become a norm for both teams to agree on an annual work program at the start of FY. It would improve the effectiveness of the program further if the WBI team also coordinated more closely with the country team in its implementation of the agreed work program. At times, agreed courses were not implemented due to the lack of financial resources. This could have been avoided had the country management team been informed of the situation (we could have mobilized external resources in the field to augment the WBI resources).
Relatively well-perceived relationships between WBI and the country teams may be contributing to the positive assessment of WBI activities' alignment with CAS and integration with operations. Nine respondents commented favorably that WBI's activities are aligned with country assistance strategies, while two respondents expressed the need for more decisive alignment. Eight respondents commented that WBI activities are well coordinated with country programs and contributed to projects, while two said they would like to see more consultation and integration.
4  Resources
Respondents from all regions, except LAC, expressed the need for WBI to increase its resources human (five respondents) and/or financial (three respondents). Two respondents asked that WBI concentrate on fewer activities and avoid extending its focus. As one person wrote, just as "quality and coordination were improving, WBI country budgets were substantially cut thus limiting the opportunity for strategic interventions and high impact."
Five respondents expressed the need for WBI to develop staff capacity. They would like staff/speakers/trainers with highly specialized skills to be responsive to the country needs and offer high quality programs. As one respondent commented, WBI needs "real practitioners that can discuss the `nuts and bolts' of reform and answer pointed questions rather than resource persons that speak in rather general terms."
In addition, five respondents acknowledged the importance of local WBI staff and how effective they are. Four respondents said that they would like to have a WBI staff member posted locally. Two also suggested better resource allocation for this purpose.
In contrast to the generally positive reactions to locally based WBI staff, some respondents also indicated their frustration with what appeared to be the limited decision-making authority granted to WBI liaisons with the country teams. A comment from one person illustrates this concern. He noted that the liaison between WBI and his country team has the best intentions and works hard in listening to the team's demands. Nonetheless, the respondent observed, "the liaison seems to have no power to make thing happen within WBI. As a result the response time to needs that are central to our team is over a year. That means that we can't use the opportunities we constantly have to make a difference with WBI's help."
Several people mentioned their concerns about the unexpected logistical burdens that WBI activities occasionally impose on country offices. Here is an illustrative comment: "WBI should also ensure that when they engage in a program they fully commit to its organization [country] team members have complained that some WBI events require a lot of the CMTs' time in logistics, etc. which is counterproductive."
Suggestions about WBI activities
Ten respondents suggested topics that they want WBI to cover according to the country's specific needs. Half of the suggestions were specifically related to ongoing projects or initiatives. In addition, there was a request to focus on the "how to" aspect rather than "why" or "what to do."
As for the delivery approach, one respondent mentioned that he would like WBI to contribute to a "large-scale policy reform" rather than project-level interventions. Another respondent asked how WBI can "pull together the various WBI activities into a cohesive, critical mass rather than a seeming cluster of useful interventions."
In addition, respondents from AFR (2), ECA (1), and LAC (1) indicated that they would like a feedback/follow-up system of activities and results after the events.
5  On a critical note, some respondents complained that WBI's activities were "largely supply driven" or not suitably responsive to the country's needs. As one person noted, there are still "entrepreneurs" within WBI who are not effectively using the locally based WBI coordinator, with detrimental consequences for the use of staff times, budgets, and contracts for consultants. Still another person asked that WBI "focus on the agreed program and avoid apparent incentives to WBI staff to build new activities all the time."
Suggested improvement in WB/WBI processes
For better coordination of the activities, some respondents mentioned coordination within WBI or with other Bank groups. Three respondents asked for better coordination within WBI, especially more effective use of regional coordinators in planning/organizing events. One respondent positively assessed WBI's work with other parts of the Bank group and another suggested coordinating with IFC.
In addition, eight respondents mentioned the positive contribution of specific staff members in the success of the activities. One mentioned that there can be a direct feedback system on this aspect, noting that "the variation (of TTLs) in WBI is very high."
Next steps
WBIEG will repeat the survey of CMTs in early FY08, asking respondents in each focus country their opinions of WBI activities in FY07. The number of desired respondents per country will likely be increased to three from two.

doc.abstracts: This paper summarizes the World Bank Institute's (WBI) performance in its 34 focus countries in FY06 from the perspective of operational staff, the Institute's Evaluation Group (WBIEG) surveyed 61 senior members of country management teams (CMT) in early FY07. The surveys asked respondents to provide their opinions of WBI's activities in the countries for which they were responsible. This report concludes that WBIEG will repeat the survey of CMTs in early FY08, asking respondents in each focus country their opinions of WBI activities in FY07. The survey was intentionally brief to encourage responses, and the reader should be aware that responses reflect opinions and perceptions about WBI's performance and effectiveness.
